documents.document: "Self-pity in its early stages is as snug as a feather mattress. Only when it hardens does it become uncomfortable." - Maya Angelou
"I feel that the greatest reward for doing is the opportunity to do more." - Jonas Salk
"Creative minds have always been known to survive any kind of bad training." - Anna Freud
"Man is free at the moment he wishes to be." - Voltaire
"Freedom is nothing else but a chance to be better." - Albert Camus
"Sometimes the first duty of intelligent men is the restatement of the obvious." - George Orwell
"To keep your marriage brimming, With love in the loving cup, -Whenever u're wrong, admit it; Whenever you're right, shut up." - Ogden Nash
"Nothing is so soothing to our self-esteem as to find our bad traits in our forebears. It seems to absolve us." - Van Wyck Brooks
"If we are to keep our democracy, there must be one commandment: Thou shalt not ration justice." - Learned Hand
"humanity i love you because when you're hard up you pawn your intelligence to buy a drink" - E.E. Cummings
"Nature has given men one tongue and two ears, that we may hear twice as much as we speak." - Epictetus
"Thoughts are but dreams till their effects be tried." - William Shakespeare
"Love does not consist in gazing at each other but in looking together in the same direction." - Antoine de Saint
"Words ought to be a little wild for they are the assault of thoughts on the unthinking." - John Maynard Keynes
"There is nothing more deceptive than an obvious fact." - Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
"Democracy is the most difficult of all forms of government, since it requires the widest spread of intelligence." - Will and Ariel Durant
"All happy families resemble each other; each unhappy family is unhappy in its own way." - Leo Tolstoy
Oops sorry wrong address
NYBuff: Brooklyn: FDNY Now on scene with a 5 Alarm Fire at 346 East 29 St / Box 2439, Heavy Fire on the 4, 5, 6 floor... http://nybuff. ...
"All happy families resemble each other; each unhappy family is unhappy in its own way." - Leo Tolstoy
"Knowledge alone effects emancipation. As fire is indispensable to cooking, so knowledge is essential to deliverance." - Shankara
"If you begin by saying, 'Thou shalt not lie,' there is no longer any possibility of political action." - Jean-Paul Sartre
"Boredom is a vital problem for the moralist, since at least half the sins of mankind are caused by the fear of it." - Bertrand Russell
"Simplicity is the essence of the great, the true, and the beautiful in art." - George Sand
"Too many parents make life hard for their children by trying, too zealously, to make it easy for them." - Ben Franklin
"There are three ingredients in the good life: learning, earning and yearning." - Christopher Morley
"Life is a gamble, at terrible odds - if it was a bet, you wouldn't take it." - Tom Stoppard
"The world is a comedy to those who think, a tragedy to those who feel." - Horace Walpole
"Most human beings have an almost infinite capacity for taking things for granted." - Aldous Huxley
"No absolute is going to make the lion lie down with the lamb unless the lamb is inside." - D. H. Lawrence
"There is no cure for birth and death save to enjoy the interval." - George Santayana
"Life shrinks or expands in proportion to one's courage." - Anais Nin
"Aspire, break bounds. Endeavor to be good, and better still, best." - Robert Browning
"You can make mistakes, but you aren't a failure until you start blaming others for those mistakes." - John Wooden
"The vocation of every man and woman is to serve other people." - Leo Tolstoy
"Pardon one offense, and you encourage the commission of many." - Publilius Syrus
"Tell me and I may forget. Show me and I may remember. Involve me and I will understand." - Chinese proverb
"Every great mistake has a halfway moment, a split second when it can be recalled and perhaps remedied." - Pearl S. Buck
"The last temptation is the greatest treason: To do the right deed for the wrong reason." - T. S. Eliot
"I have often thought what a melancholy world this would be without children; and what an inhuman world without the aged." - S. T. Coleridge
Far and away the best prize that life offers is the chance to work hard at work worth doing." - Theodore Roosevelt
"If we don't believe in freedom of expression for people we despise, we don't believe in it at all." - Noam Chomsky
Oops
@NYBuff: Brooklyn: Ave F and E 5 st. Hatzolah on scene with an overturned vehicle. Requesting ESU to upright.... http://nybuff.us/iE9ig
"During times of universal deceit, telling the truth becomes a revolutionary act." - George Orwell
"Society often forgives the criminal; it never forgives the dreamer." - Oscar Wilde
"All human power is a compound of time and patience." - Honore de Balzac
"The punishment which the wise suffer who refuse to take part in the government, is to live under the government of worse men." - Plato
"The gallery in which the reporters sit has become a fourth estate of the realm." - Thomas Babington, Lord Macaulay
"He that is of the opinion money will do everything may well be suspected of doing everything for money." - Benjamin Franklin
"Good people are good because they've come to wisdom through failure. We get very little wisdom from success, you know." - William Saroyan
"Be swift to hear, slow to speak, slow to wrath." - New Testament, James i 19
"I have found the best way to give advice to your children is to find out what they want and then advise them to do it." - Harry S. Truman
"Don't walk in front of me, I may not follow. Don't walk behind me, I may not lead. Walk beside me and be my friend." - Albert Camus
"Man's loneliness is but his fear of life." - Eugene O'Neill
"And the day came when the risk [it took] to remain tight in the bud was more painful than the risk it took to bloom." - Anais Nin
"The cocks may crow, but it's the hen that lays the egg." - Margaret Thatcher
"Our remedies oft in ourselves do lie, which we ascribe to Heaven." - William Shakespeare
"The only fool bigger than the person who knows it all is the person who argues with him." - Stanislaw Jerszy Lec
"I can teach anybody how 2 get what they want out of life. The problem is that I can't find anybody who can tell me what they want."M. Twain
"If you think education is expensive, try ignorance." - Derek Bok
"Tis our true policy to steer clear of permanent alliances with any portion of the foreign world." - George Washington
"All men should strive to learn before they die what they are running from, and to, and why." - James Thurber
"The young man knows the rules, but the old man knows the exceptions." - Oliver Wendell Holmes
"It is dangerous to be right when the government is wrong." - Voltaire
"The soul should always stand ajar, ready to welcome the ecstatic experience." - Emily Dickinson
"Action without intelligence is a form of insanity, but intelligence without action is d greatest form of stupidity in the world." -Charles
"The more corrupt the state, the more numerous the laws." - Tacitus
"I have always imagined that paradise will be a kind of library." - Jorge Luis Borges
"To see a world in a grain of sand, & a heaven in a wild flower, Hold infinity in d palm of ur hand, & eternity in an hour." - William Blake
"A desk is a dangerous place from which to view the world." - John le Carre
"There are 2 kinds of fool. One says, 'This is old, and therefore good.' And one says, 'This is new, and therefore better.' " - John Brunner
"To love and be loved is to feel the sun from both sides." - David Viscott
"Optimism is essential to achievement and it is also the foundation of courage and true progress." - Nicholas Murray Butler
"Difficulties are meant to rouse, not discourage. The human spirit is to grow strong by conflict." - William Ellery Channing
"Sixty years ago I knew everything; now I know nothing; education is a progressive discovery of our own ignorance." - Will Durant
"Real glory springs from the silent conquest of ourselves." - Joseph P. Thompson
"People who have what they want are very fond of telling people who haven't what they want that they don't want it." - Mark Twain
"The most difficult thing in the world is to know how to do a thing and to watch somebody else doing it wrong, without comment." -T.H. White
"The greatest tragedy is indifference." - Red Cross
"The punishment which the wise suffer who refuse to take part in the government, is to live under the government of worse men." - Plato
"It takes less time to do a thing right, than it does to explain why you did it wrong." - Henry Wadsworth Longfellow
Wild honey smells of freedom. The dust - of sunlight. The mouth of a young girl, like a violet. But gold - smells of nothing. - Anna Akhmato
"Many people take no care of their money till they come nearly to the end of it, and others do just the same with their time." - Goethe
"Speech is conveniently located midway between thought and action, where it often substitutes for both." - John Andrew Holmes
"The shoe that fits one person pinches another; there is no recipe for living that suits all cases." - Carl Jung
"Happiness is when what you think, what you say, and what you do are in harmony." - Mohandas K. Gandhi
"Holding on to anger is like grasping a hot coal with the intent of throwing it at someone else; you are the one getting burned." - Buddha
"Most men pursue pleasure with such breathless haste they hurry past it." - Soren Kierkegaard
"Laughter is the shortest distance between two people." - Victor Borge
"Losing an illusion makes you wiser than finding a truth." - Ludwig Borne
"A lawyer is a person who writes a 10,000 word document and calls it a 'brief'." - Franz Kafka
"Ultimately, the only power to which man should aspire is that which he exercises over himself." - Elie Wiesel
"Blessed are those who can give without remembering and take without forgetting." - Elizabeth Bibesco
"One kind word can warm three winter months." - Japanese proverb
"In politics stupidity is not a handicap." - Napoleon I Bonaparte
"Losing an illusion makes you wiser than finding a truth." - Ludwig Borne
"What lies behind us and what lies before us are tiny matters compared to what lies within us." - Ralph Waldo Emerson
"The best portion of a good man's life is the little, nameless, unremembered acts of kindness and love." - William Wordsworth
"Eloquence is a painting of the thoughts." - Blaise Pascal
